envVars.name: AWS_SQS_QUEUE_NAME
envVars.notes: Name or topic of the queue in the cloud

envVars.name: AWS_SQS_REGION
envVars.notes: AWS region in which the queue is defined

envVars.name: AWS_SQS_SECRET_KEY
envVars.notes: IAM secret key for access key

msgQueue.setupNotes: See the [SQS Developer Guide](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/welcome.html) for help setting up the queue service. See the [IAM User Guide](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/index.html) for help setting up the identity. The IAM User must at least be assigned the SQS *SendMessage* permission.

envVars.name: AWS_SECRETSMGR_REGION
envVars.notes: AWS region in which the secret store is defined

envVars.name: AWS_SECRETSMGR_SECRET_KEY
envVars.notes: IAM secret key for access key

secretStore.setupNotes:
See the AWS Secrets Manager [User Guide](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/secretsmanager/latest/userguide/intro.html) for help with setup. See the [IAM User Guide](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/index.html) for general help with users and security.

When actually adding secrets, add them simply as Plaintext -- no separate key and value. AWS Secrets Manager console defaults to a "compound" secret that contains a *list* of key:value pairs rather than just a single plaintext value.
